title: Mastering AutoGen: Building Custom Orchestrators for Multi-Agent Control
summary: This tutorial addresses the consistency issues found in AutoGen's default GroupChat by introducing a custom 'Orchestrator' class. The speaker demonstrates how to manually control agent conversation flows, implementing 'Sequential' and 'Broadcast' patterns to build a robust pipeline that performs database engineering followed by multi-format data visualization.

steps.action: Execute baseline Postgres Agent using standard AutoGen GroupChat
steps.reasoning: Demonstrates the initial capability of the agent to query databases but highlights the lack of fine-grained control over the conversation flow.

steps.action: Develop custom 'Orchestrator' class to replace GroupChatManager
steps.reasoning: Establishes a framework to manually direct message passing between agents, overcoming the non-deterministic nature of the default manager.
Enforces a linear dependency chain (Admin -> Engineer -> Analyst -> PM), ensuring tasks like SQL generation and verification happen in the correct order.

steps.action: Define 'function_chat' logic to handle tool execution explicitly
steps.reasoning: Ensures that when an agent invokes a tool (e.g., run_sql), the system pauses to execute it and injects the result back into the flow for the next agent.

steps.action: Implement 'broadcast_conversation' method for parallel task distribution
steps.reasoning: Allows a single source of data to be sent to multiple agents simultaneously, useful for generating multiple output formats (Text, JSON, YAML) from one dataset.

steps.action: Configure specialized Data Viz agents with exclusive file-writing tools
steps.reasoning: Isolates functionality by giving specific agents unique tools, reducing hallucination and ensuring each agent performs only its designated reporting format.

steps.action: Chain Data Engineering and Data Viz orchestrators into a single pipeline
steps.reasoning: Demonstrates the power of modular agentic workflows by feeding the real-time SQL query results from the first team directly into the reporting workflow of the second team.

key_takeaways: Default AutoGen GroupChat managers can lack the deterministic control needed for complex, multi-step engineering tasks.
Custom Orchestrators allow developers to define specific architectural patterns like Sequential (linear) and Broadcast (one-to-many) flows.
Separating agents into specialized teams (e.g., Engineering vs. Visualization) with exclusive tools increases reliability and reduces errors.
Manually handling 'function_chat' ensures that tool outputs are correctly propagated to the next agent in the chain.
